Grab&Go Meals Continue
We‚Äôve had questions about the availability of Grab&Go meals in light of Gov. Baker‚Äôs recent orders.
STGRSD will continue to offer meals to ALL students in need, free of charge, during the cancellation of classes.

Meals will be available for daily pick up at the Powder Mill School Entrance and the Gran-Val Scoop from 11:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m.. Meals will be a cold grab-and-go to be consumed off-site. Meal pick up will include: Lunch for today and Breakfast for tomorrow. Drive-thru pick-up stations will be set up outside each building. Please remain in your car and meals will be brought to you. No need to sign up to receive these meals.

The Town of Tolland is delivering meals to families, but needs contact information and addresses. If you are a Tolland resident who is interested in the Grab&Go meal program, please call the Tolland Town Hall at 413-258-4794 or email: selectmen@tolland-ma.com and provide information about your address and the number of children who need meals.
The Tolland meals will include multiple days of a cold Grab&Go lunch and breakfast.

The SRS Drama Club is pleased to present its fall production: ALMOST, MAINE.
Written by Massachusetts native John Cariani, the play features a series of 10-minute vignettes that zero in on the close relationships among the residents of a remote New England township. What kinds of jobs are there in healthcare? SRS students had a chance to find out by attending the Healthcare Careers Exploration Night at Springfield Technical Community College. Students and Career Facilitator, Maryanne Margiotta, visited the school's state-of-the-art medical simulation lab and witnessed a simulated "live" birth and a realistic dramatization of an emergency room crisis. They also listened to heartbeats and respiration, tried their hand at using laparoscopic surgery tools, and practiced operating ultrasound equipment. They learned from medical students and professors what to expect in a wide range of medical fields.

As part of STEM Week, students in grades K-3 saw apples decompose through a teacher demonstration. They learned the parts of an apple and heard from a local farmer about the steps of the apple farming process, how the apples get to our homes, and what happens to the apples that the orchard does not sell. The students engaged in an apple journey simulation where they moved pom poms that represented the different parts of the apple's journey and to see how many apples are wasted and how many are used.

Attention STGRSD Families:
Southwick and several surrounding communities are now categorized as 'High Risk' EEE communities by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. With the safety of students, families, and the community as our primary concern, we are implementing the follow action plan effective immediately:

- All practices will end PRIOR TO 6:00 p.m.
- All outdoor home games will be scheduled to ensure they end prior to 6:30 p.m.
- All outdoor away games in towns or cities categorized as high risk will be reviewed, and, in conjunction with the host schools, start times will be adjusted appropriately.
- The athletic trainer will have insect repellent available to any participants in games or practices upon request. Student-athletes are encouraged to utilize the repellent.

We are continually monitoring the situation and are prepared to make adjustments as needed moving forward.

For the latest information on EEE from the MA Department of Public Health, visit their web-site:
https://www.mass.gov/mosquito-borne-diseases

The Diversified Learning Experience (DLE) Program at Southwick Regional School is a highly structured intense internship program designed to provide students the opportunity to gain valuable experience in the industrial/business/service communities and to gain competencies essential to success in the work place. Students in the program usually spend two periods of the day in academic classes and attend work-based learning experiences during the remaining time for a full semester.

This week 21 seniors are ready to begin their DLE internships at various local businesses, schools, hospitals and community organizations! This semester-long experience will give them a firsthand glimpse of future careers and enable them to learn and practice valuable workplace skills.

Southwick Regional School seniors Clare Stratton, Gabriela Peterson and Emily Martin, were selected to participate this summer in the first Student Ambassador Program of the Teen Mini Medical School held at Baystate Noble Hospital in Westfield. For six weeks this summer our students, along with 6 other area high school students, received an intensive, hands-on introduction to a variety of different departments at the hospital. They worked one-on-one with many hospital personnel, enabling them to observe hospital procedures and get an in-depth introduction to a variety of careers in the healthcare field.

This photo was taken at their Graduation Ceremony at the hospital on August 21. We are so proud of all of them!

At today's Staff Opening Day, School Resource Officer Taggart organized Stop the Bleed Training for all staff members.
Stop the Bleed is a national awareness campaign and call-to-action. Stop the Bleed is intended to cultivate grassroots efforts that encourage bystanders to become trained, equipped, and empowered to help in a bleeding emergency before professional help arrives.

Volunteers came from near and far, including the Southwick Police Department, Southwick Fire Department, Holyoke Police Department, Agawam Police Department, State Police, Baystate and Noble Hospital ICU & ER Nurses, our own SRS School Nurse Marcia Lamoureaux, and School Resource Officer Taggart.

Thank you to Officer Taggart and EVERYONE who participated in this important, life-saving training!!!
